Posts.Content: mke wrote: I'm about 5 weeks post bilateral mast. and there is still some puckering of my scars.  At the end of this month I will lose my "platinum" (my onc. phrase) supplemental health coverage.  I am getting what I can while I can - new glasses, first in years; teeth cleaning, overdue; and if it is not too soon breast protheses. However ill fitting ones will be worse than none I would guess and I don't want to exploit the insurance for the pure pleasure of it.   In truth I am not much into being fashionable or looking "right" and would probably only use protheses when more formal wear would look odd without them. I don't want any custom molded jobs, just something serviceable. Log in to post a reply

Posts.Title: I'm in the hospital AlaskaDeb spar2

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2008 01:28AM mke wrote: I haven't a clue about layered microcalcs or what to do about them, but I wanted you to know that someone had heard you. I think I'd feel bewildered too and not really inclined to jump for joy. You haven't gotten any definitive word, so you're probably still in that waiting stage which is the worst part of all. I guess there isn't too much you can do but wait until Monday and insist on another meeting with your surgeon after she has gotten the radiologist report. She should be able to explain it all to you. I'd also mention your treatment by that radiologist. It may be that your surgeon has no choice in who she sends her patients to for exams - but maybe she does. I haven't had the same thing but I have had exasperated doctors or technicians a couple times. Try not to take it too personally - he was probably suffering from an excess of turkey or something.
Posts.Title: Now what to do? ccare ccare

Posts.Content: Dec 27, 2008 11:39PM mke wrote: YOU rule, meaning it is your body and ultimately your decision. You listen to what they say, your surgeon will translate the radiologists report for you and then you decide. The recommendation may well be to monitor every 6 months, more for the fibrocyctic disease than the microcalcs. Or it might be back for another try at a biopsy of the primary cyst. Try not to worry too much (silly advice I know, but try anyway).
Posts.Title: Now what to do? ccare ccare

Posts.Content: Jun 27, 2009 09:08PM mke wrote: You will cry when you are damn good and ready to cry.  And you might not cry at all.  I'm thinking (hoping) too that the "advanced" might just mean that it has spread to the lymph nodes.  I think it will take a little time to determine the grade and hormone receptor status, which will tell you more.  Without a whole lot of things like bone scans and ultra-sounds it really is impossible to say much more about your cancer. This a good place for both information and support.
Posts.Title: When do I cry? seaofhope one-L

Posts.Content: Dec 12, 2008 02:10AM mke wrote: This is a really interesting question, a multilayered one. For sure I was sick while going through chemo - by any definition of the word I was sick, by just about any way a person could manifest illness I did it. (I'll spare you the details) So I guess I was sick. If I had to get health insurance it would be difficult, if I had to get life insurance (a concept that has always escaped me) I wouldn't be able to or I would have to pay an awful lot. They surely won't take my blood donation which pains me because the donations of others kept me going. So I guess I am sort of tainted or something. I have lingering side-effects, my fingers and feet are bit numb, my nails are sort of crumbly, my hair still does peculiar things. I have to be a bit mindful because I've had axial node dissections on both sides twice. So I guess I'm a bit disabled. Three rounds of breast cancer but I still don't regard myself as sick. It probably will kill me, I am not in denial about that. But at present I feel pretty good. I don't feel sick.
Posts.Title: Do you consider yourself sick? shockedat39 kmccraw423

Posts.Content: Dec 13, 2008 02:21AM mke wrote: It really is a matter of semantics. To me life is a terminal disease, no one gets out of here alive. Sick - well to me that's aches and pains, coughing, barfing, pooping uncontrollably (or not being able to poop at all), dizziness, sneezing, fatigue, etc. I don't have any of that: ergo I'm not sick.
Posts.Title: Do you consider yourself sick? shockedat39 kmccraw423

Anybody else had this? Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jun 28, 2009 11:10AM mke wrote: Dear Ead's husband. Try not to be an ass#### and especially try not to call your wife names. In case you haven't noticed she's got some stuff to deal with at the moment.  Your daughter will survive being yelled at after the third call to dinner.  Actually she lucky to get a 3rd call - my sons would not have, we have a one notice rule here. You can bet your behind that I am still lecturing my boys, I sure am not going to let them do dumb stuff and smile kindly on - what kind of mother would do that?  I think my guys will remember me yelling at them for one thing and another, and being the sensible lads they are they will laugh about it and admit they deserved it.  Likely your daughter is just as sensible. Mr. Ead, you really should think about your drinking.  I drink too and probably more than I should, but I have found that alcohol does not improve judgement.  Unfortunately  it loosens both the tongue and the brain connections.  When drinking one should probably count to about 500 before saying anything.
Posts.Title: Cruel words from husband ead WendyV

Posts.Content: mke wrote: I think Binnie warned me about this, and I have been careful.  We have a female kitten that I tried to get spayed last week, but they thought she was too young.  She has been desperate to get outside lately, I think she is going into heat.  Yesterday she escaped and when I grabbed her I was scratched on both arms.  I've had BC on both sides but many more lymph nodes removed on the right.  Of course I scrubbed right away and spread polysporin on everything. However, this morning it is clear that there is inflamation in several spots on the right side. I really don't like running to the doctor for everything and my husband says wait a day and see.  On the other hand (pun intended) I really don't want to get lymphedema.   My plan is to monitor closely and if anything gets worse act fast. Any opinions? Log in to post a reply

Posts.Content: Jan 7, 2008 12:47PM mke wrote: About the tingling fingers - read up about ulnar tunnel syndrome (or something like that).  The ulnar nerve runs from the shoulder down to the hand.  One branch of it enervates the little finger and the outside of the ring finger.  Check and see if the sensation is different on the two sides of your ring finger.  If it is, you almost certainly have an ulnar nerve injury. Start protecting your right elbow.  I wear a pad on mine sometimes, mostly to keep me from leaning on it.

Posts.Content: Nov 2, 2008 09:23PM mke wrote: In so far as you can, cut yourself and everyone else some slack. Everyone's tensions are high and everyone is feeling fear/guilt/anger and a whole lot of other things. Don't take anything that another does or says too seriously. Your mother is not the first person to ignore a health problem and it does not reflect on you or your siblings that she did this so don't feel guilty. (easy to say I know, but try not to) There isn't much you can do except cope as best you can. Hospice is a good suggestion and perhaps, depending on the age of your son and your mother's condition, a couple of days off school to visit grandma might be appropriate. So sorry you are going through this.

Posts.Content: Mar 21, 2008 01:07PM mke wrote: Welcome to the club, sorry you had to join.  I got a pair of puffies from the nurse in the surgeon's office after the meeting with him when I decided on the bilateral.  Actually they are still there in the box, I haven't used them, can't quite figure out what to do with them - bra, camisole?  I think it is a promotional thing by Amoena (sp?).  And the visiting nurses left a lot of tape and bandages behind. In Toronto, there is a lot of support stuff available, Willow, Wellspring, and Princess Margaret hosp.  Willow is mostly an information resource now I think, but they used to do peer support.  You could google them and see what they have now. How are you feeling?

Posts.Title: Mastectomy - how long? mollyr AnnNYC

Posts.Content: Sep 22, 2009 01:12PM mke wrote: Well geez, talk about a lot to deal with!  And it seems a bit of anxiety is only to be expected. There is a Canadian section so you might find a kindred spirit close by but SK is a big place.  I do feel for you, dealing with another round of BC and your husband must be hard, not to mention livestock.  That is way too many unrelenting needs. You didn't ask for advice, but have have you tried Biotene mouthwash or toothpaste?  They help some.  I smoked for years and finally kicked it with patches and Zyban.  I was on taxol (taxotere's cousin) with my second round of BC and I will say it was awful.  Strange - it's easy for some, and ghastly for others and no one seems to know why.  Heating pads helped a bit with the joint/muscle pain and I was on a diet of beef broth and fruit yogurt for the last couple weeks. Let us know how it goes for you.

Posts.Content: Jul 26, 2009 10:02PM mke wrote: One does feel sort of out of control at the stage, things are happening too fast to process.  You had brusque treatment and it's good that you are consulting another surgeon. Don't pay too much attention to the horror stories that people like to tell.  I had a bilateral and walked out of the hospital 24 hours later.  Sure there was some discomfort and even pain but nothing that Tylenol 3's couldn't control.

Posts.Content: May 15, 2008 09:56AM mke wrote: I never even considered reconstruction.  I considered a bilateral when I had BC for the 2nd time but the surgeon discouraged me and we came to a compromise.  When I had yet a 3rd round I was adamant that I wanted a bilateral with no reconstruction. I'm 62, I was never spectacularly endowed, married nearly 40 years to a man who fortunately lacks a breast fixation.  It's been about 3 months since my surgery and I have yet to go get breast forms.   The way I dress (for the most part), no one notices my lack of breasts.  I will get some prostheses because I have some clothes that are just not going to fit right without them, but I have a feeling that they will be spending a lot of time in a drawer.
